channel.title: How do i make a server more stable?
channel.description: This is a project insanity server, how do i make a server more stable?

item.title: How do i make a server more stable?
item.dc:creator: @imsuperman05 imsuperman05
item.description:
@imsuperman05 wrote:

[quote=“Fridder, post:13, topic:415852”]There hasn’t been a PI released with fixed memory leaks.
Hold on I think there might be one…
No there’s not it got removed from the download section[/quote]
Mine will have no memory leaks at all. Just wait for it…

Fridder:

Fix the memory leaks, download InnovationX off the Server Download section, then rip & convert the server stability shit right from it. It says it can hold 2k+ players with no lag.

Don’t believe what people make up.

Read full topic

item.title: How do i make a server more stable?
item.dc:creator: @iloveyou12341 iloveyou12341
item.description:
@iloveyou12341 wrote:

[quote=“Fridder, post:4, topic:415852”]A memory leak, in computer science (or leakage, in this context), occurs when a computer program consumes memory but is unable to release it back to the operating system. In object-oriented programming, a memory leak happens when an object is stored in memory but cannot be accessed by the running code. A memory leak has symptoms similar to a number of other problems and generally can only be diagnosed by a programmer with access to the program source code; however, many people refer to any unwanted increase in memory usage as a memory leak, though this is not strictly accurate from a technical perspective.

A memory leak can diminish the performance of the computer by reducing the amount of available memory. Eventually, in the worst case, too much of the available memory may become allocated and all or part of the system or device stops working correctly, the application fails, or the system slows down unacceptably due to thrashing.
Memory leaks may not be serious or even detectable by normal means. In modern operating systems, normal memory used by an application is released when the application terminates. This means that a memory leak in a program that only runs for a short time may not be noticed and is rarely serious.
Leaks that are much more serious include:
where the program runs for an extended time and consumes additional memory over time, such as background tasks on servers, but especially in embedded devices which may be left running for many years.
where new memory is allocated frequently for one-time tasks, such as when rendering the frames of a computer game or animated video.
where the program is able to request memory — such as shared memory — that is not released, even when the program terminates.
where memory is very limited, such as in an embedded system or portable device.
where the leak occurs within the operating system or memory manager.
where the leak is the responsibility of a system device driver.
where running on an operating systems that does not automatically release memory on program termination. Often on such machines if memory is lost, it can only be reclaimed by a reboot, an example of such a system being AmigaOS.

Memory leaks are a common error in programming, especially when using languages that have no built-in automatic garbage collection, such as C and C++. Typically, a memory leak occurs because dynamically allocated memory has become unreachable. The prevalence of memory leak bugs has led to the development of a number of debugging tools to detect unreachable memory. IBM Rational Purify, BoundsChecker, Valgrind, Insure++ and memwatch are some of the more popular memory debuggers for C and C++ programs. “Conservative” garbage collection capabilities can be added to any programming language that lacks it as a built-in feature, and libraries for doing this are available for C and C++ programs. A conservative collector finds and reclaims most, but not all, unreachable memory.

Source: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Memory_leak[/quote]

Do you think insidia-X has memory leaks? thats the source i’m using.

Read full topic
item.source: How do i make a server more stable?

item.title: How do i make a server more stable?
item.dc:creator: @Fridder Fridder
item.description:
@Fridder wrote:

A memory leak, in computer science (or leakage, in this context), occurs when a computer program consumes memory but is unable to release it back to the operating system. In object-oriented programming, a memory leak happens when an object is stored in memory but cannot be accessed by the running code. A memory leak has symptoms similar to a number of other problems and generally can only be diagnosed by a programmer with access to the program source code; however, many people refer to any unwanted increase in memory usage as a memory leak, though this is not strictly accurate from a technical perspective.

A memory leak can diminish the performance of the computer by reducing the amount of available memory. Eventually, in the worst case, too much of the available memory may become allocated and all or part of the system or device stops working correctly, the application fails, or the system slows down unacceptably due to thrashing.
Memory leaks may not be serious or even detectable by normal means. In modern operating systems, normal memory used by an application is released when the application terminates. This means that a memory leak in a program that only runs for a short time may not be noticed and is rarely serious.
Leaks that are much more serious include:
where the program runs for an extended time and consumes additional memory over time, such as background tasks on servers, but especially in embedded devices which may be left running for many years.
where new memory is allocated frequently for one-time tasks, such as when rendering the frames of a computer game or animated video.
where the program is able to request memory — such as shared memory — that is not released, even when the program terminates.
where memory is very limited, such as in an embedded system or portable device.
where the leak occurs within the operating system or memory manager.
where the leak is the responsibility of a system device driver.
where running on an operating systems that does not automatically release memory on program termination. Often on such machines if memory is lost, it can only be reclaimed by a reboot, an example of such a system being AmigaOS.

Memory leaks are a common error in programming, especially when using languages that have no built-in automatic garbage collection, such as C and C++. Typically, a memory leak occurs because dynamically allocated memory has become unreachable. The prevalence of memory leak bugs has led to the development of a number of debugging tools to detect unreachable memory. IBM Rational Purify, BoundsChecker, Valgrind, Insure++ and memwatch are some of the more popular memory debuggers for C and C++ programs. “Conservative” garbage collection capabilities can be added to any programming language that lacks it as a built-in feature, and libraries for doing this are available for C and C++ programs. A conservative collector finds and reclaims most, but not all, unreachable memory.

Source: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Memory_leak

Read full topic
